column10: Canada

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Explore the migration of people across the world.

column10: xSlug
column14: note
column15: relatedQuestionText

column3: The total number of people living in a given country that were born in another country. This measures the cumulative migrant stock.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Share of the population that were born in another country
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Change in the number of international immigrants in the previous five years
column3: The change in the total number of migrants living in a given country compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more migrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Change in the number of international immigrants in the previous five years, per 1,000 people
column3: The change in the total number of migrants living in a given country compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more migrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

column3: Total number of people that have left the country.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Share of the population born in that country that now live in another country
column3: The total number of people that have left the country, as a share of the current population.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Change in the number of emigrants in the previous five years
column3: The total number of people born in that country that are now living in another country, compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more emigrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Change in the number of emigrants in the previous five years, per 1,000 people
column3: The total number of people born in that country that are now living in another country, compared to five years ago. A positive number indicates there are now more emigrants living in a given country; a negative number means there are fewer.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

column3: Net migration is the total the number of immigrants (people moving into a given country) minus the number of emigrants (people moving out of the country) over the previous five years. It is expressed as average annual net number of migrants.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

column3: Net migration rate is the number of immigrants (people moving into a given country) minus the number of emigrants (people moving out of the country) in the previous five years, divided by the person-years lived by the population of the receiving country over that period. It is expressed as average annual net number of migrants per 1,000 population.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

column3: The total number of children under 18 years old that were born in another country. This measures the cumulative immigrant stock, and should not be confused with the flow of new immigrants.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of child immigrants per 1,000 people
column3: The total number of children under 18 years old that were born in another country, per 1,000 people in the host country. This measures the cumulative immigrant stock, and should not be confused with the flow of new immigrants.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

column3: The total number of children under 15 years old that were born in another country. This measures the cumulative immigrant stock, and should not be confused with the flow of new immigrants.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of child immigrants per 1,000 people
column3: The total number of children under 15 years old that were born in another country, per 1,000 people in the host country. This measures the cumulative immigrant stock, and should not be confused with the flow of new immigrants.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of refugees living in the host country
column3: Total number of refugees living in the host country. This measures the total number of refugees living in the country; not the number of arrivals per year.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of refugees living in the host country per 1,000 people
column3: Total number of refugees living in the host country, measured per 1,000 people. This measures the total number of refugees living in the country; not the number of arrivals per year.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of refugees from the country of origin
column3: Total number of refugees by country of origin. This measures the total number of refugees from the country; not the number per year.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of refugees from the country of origin per 1,000 people
column3: Total number of refugees by country of origin, measured per 1,000 people. This measures the total number of refugees from the country; not the number per year.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of pending asylum applications by destination country
column3: The total number of people in the country whose application for asylum or refugee status is pending at any stage in the asylum procedure.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of pending asylum applications by destination country per 100,000
column3: The number of people in the country whose application for asylum or refugee status is pending at any stage in the asylum procedure, expressed per 100,000 people in the host country.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of pending asylum applications by origin country
column3: The total number of people from a given country who has a pending application for asylum or refugee status in any other country.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of pending asylum applications by origin country per 100,000
column3: The number of people from a given country who has a pending application for asylum or refugee status in any other country, expressed per 100,000 people in the origin country.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Annual number of resettled refugees by destination
column3: The number of refugees that were resettled in the country per year. Resettlement is the change in status of a refugee when they go from an asylum country/state to another territory that has agreed to admit them and ultimately grant them permanent residence.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Annual number of resettled refugees by destination per 100,000 people
column3: The number of refugees that were resettled in the country per year. This is measured per 100,000 people in the host country. Resettlement is the change in status of a refugee when they go from an asylum country/state to another territory that has agreed to admit them and ultimately grant them permanent residence.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Annual number of resettled refugees by origin
column3: The number of refugees from the country that were resettled in another country per year. Resettlement is the change in status of a refugee when they go from an asylum country/state to another territory that has agreed to admit them and ultimately grant them permanent residence.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Annual number of resettled refugees by origin per 100,000 people
column3: The number of refugees from the country that were resettled in another country per year. This is measured per 100,000 people of the origin country. Resettlement is the change in status of a refugee when they go from an asylum country/state to another territory that has agreed to admit them and ultimately grant them permanent residence.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: New internal displacements due to conflict
column3: The number of new displacements within a given country as a result of conflict and violence. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, or violations of human rights and have not crossed an internationally-recognized state border.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: New internal displacements due to conflict per 100 people
column3: The number of new displacements within a given country as a result of conflict and violence, measured per 100 people. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, or violations of human rights and have not crossed an internationally-recognized state border.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: New internal displacement due to disasters
column3: The number of new displacements within a given country as a result of disasters. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of a natural or human-made disaster.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: New internal displacements due to disasters per 100 people
column3: The number of new displacements within a given country as a result of disasters, measured per 100 people. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of a natural or human-made disaster.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of people internally displaced due to conflict
column3: This is the number of current internal displacements: it is the cumulative sum of new displacement minus people who have returned to their homes, or have been resettled. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, or violations of human rights and have not crossed an internationally-recognized state border.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of people internally displaced due to conflict per 100 people
column3: This is the number of current internal displacements: it is the cumulative sum of new displacement minus people who have returned to their homes, or have been resettled, measured per 100 people. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, or violations of human rights and have not crossed an internationally-recognized state border.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of people internally displaced due to disasters
column3: This is the number of current internal displacements: it is the cumulative sum of new displacement minus people who have returned to their homes, or have been resettled. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of a natural or human-made disaster.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Number of people internally displaced due to disasters per 100 people
column3: This is the number of current internal displacements: it is the cumulative sum of new displacement minus people who have returned to their homes, or have been resettled, measured per 100 people. A person is defined as internally displaced if they have been forced or obliged to leave their homes as a result of a natural or human-made disaster.
column14: This indicator measures events rather than individuals. The same person could be displaced several times, and each time counts as a new displacement. Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Remittances as a share of GDP
column3: Remittances are in-kind cash transfers made from individuals in a given country to households outside of the host country.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Average fees for sending remittances in each country
column3: Remittances are in-kind cash transfers made from individuals in a given country to households outside of the host country. Transferring this money usually comes with a cost – this cost is called the remittance cost. This measures the average remittance costs of the country where immigrants are sending this money from. It is expressed as a percentage of total remittances.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions

Migration, Refugee and Asylum Data Explo: Average fees for receiving remittances in each country
column3: Remittances are in-kind cash transfers made from individuals in a given country to households outside of the host country. Transferring this money usually comes with a cost – this cost is called the remittance cost. This measures the average remittance costs of the country where immigrants are sending this money to. It is expressed as a percentage of total remittances.
column14: Data is presented as the five-year rolling average.
column15: Migration Data: Our sources and definitions
